The  Project  involves  the  construction  of  a  new  75  kilometers  (km) 
railway  line  between  Hairatan  at  the  border  with  Uzbekistan  and 
Mazar-e-Sharif  in  Afghanistan.  The  Project  represents  a  first  phase 
of  a  larger  rail  network  planned  across  the  north  and  other  parts  of 
the  country,  including  links  to  Herat,  Tajikistan,  and  Pakistan.  It  will 
expand  the  existing  transport  network  in  Afghanistan  and  improve 
substantially  internal  and  international  connectivity.  The  Project  is 
part  of  the  Transport  Strategy  and  Action  Plan  agreed  under  the 
Central  Asia  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Program.  It 
will add capacity to two transport corridors under CAREC and open 
up alternative routes of supply for national and international trade, as 
well as for humanitarian relief to Afghanistan. 
 
The  Project  has  two  components:  (i)  design  and  construction  of 
75  km  single-line  railway  and  associated 
infrastructure;  and 
(ii)  project  management,  independent  supervision,  and  institutional 
support. The Project will be executed through a fixed price and fixed 
time  delivery  engineering,  procurement,  and  construction  (EPC) 
turnkey  contract.  Once  constructed,  tested,  and  commissioned,  the 
rail service will be managed by an operator under an operation and 
maintenance contract.

efficient,  safe,  and  sustainable  transport  link  within  the  country  and 
between the country and its neighbors. Hairatan already doubles up 
as  Afghanistan's  most  important  dry  and  river  port,  acting  as  the

well  with  the  CAREC  Transport  and  Trade  Facilitation  Strategy  and 
the Action Plan. 
 
The  Project  will  be  implemented  in  line  with  ADB's  approach  to 
engaging with weakly performing countries.  
 
The Project will lead to greater economic growth and increased trade 
between  Afghanistan  and  the  region.  The  outcome  will  be  a  more 
efficient, safer, and sustainable railway transport network in northern 
Afghanistan,  resulting  in  increased  transport  volumes  and  reduced 
transport  costs.  The  Project  underpins  regional  cooperation  and 
integration in Central Asia.

It  is  proposed  that  Uzbekistan  Temir  Yullari  (Uzbekistan's  Railway 
Company, or UTY) be awarded two contracts: (i) an EPC contract for 
design and construction, and (ii) an O&M contract. 
 
Direct contracting to UTY is justified on the following grounds. First, 
the  railway  line  is  a  de  facto  extension  of  the  current  Uzbekistan 
railway  network  into  Mazar-e-Sharif.  This  is  based  on  the  current 
Uzbekistan gauge system. Using the Uzbekistan system for this first 
phase of the rail network has considerable financial and operational 
logic.  It  does  not  require  new  rolling  stock  and  the  management  of 
UTY  is  both  experienced  and  proven.  However,  this  approach  also 
makes  the  project  potentially  less  attractive  to  other  contractors  in 
the region since they would be unfamiliar with the system. 
 
Second, UTY is the only company in the region with the track record 
to  design,  procure,  and  construct  a  railway  line  based  on  the 
Uzbekistan system. UTY is also the sole operator of the Uzbekistan 
rail  network.  UTY  is  familiar  with  conditions  on  the  ground,  first  for 
construction and then for operations and maintenance. There are no 
comparable operators in the region or beyond it, with the same track 
record. 
 
Third,  UTY  has  already  preliminary  designs  for  the  line.  These  are 
based  on  past  work  commissioned  directly  by  the  Government  of 
Afghanistan.  This  design  work  increases  project  readiness  and 
saves  considerable  time  and  costs.  It  accelerates  implementation, 
which in turn translates faster into fewer bottlenecks to trade.  
 
Fourth,  UTY  has  designed  and  executed  ADB-assisted  railway 
projects in the past, including the railway link between Tashkent and 
Samarkand. The proposed Project has been given top priority by the 
most  senior  authorities  in  Uzbekistan.  It  also  fits  with  UTY's  current 
project  construction  pipeline.  The  company  has  sufficient  financial 
resources  to  implement  an  operation  of  this  nature,  and  the  right 
people and skills to manage it later.

Sixth,  ADB's  experience  in  Afghanistan  suggests  that  on  average 
only  one  company  tends  to  bid  for  a  construction  contract.  Poor

financing package and often submit bids close to that or even above. 
In addition, the procurement process often takes a long time, and in 
several  instances  has  involved  retenders.  The  result  has  been  late 
start-ups and slow project implementation. These delays have often 
led  to  changes  in  project  scope,  cost  overruns,  and  contract 
renegotiations.  If  UTY  were  to  bid  for  the  Project,  it  is  likely  that  it

bid,  then  the  Government  would  have  to  secure  the  services  of

start  from  scratch  with  the  design  work—and  later  find  ways  to 
access  information  from  Uzbekistan  on  the  gauge  and  operational 
system.  This  access  is  not  automatically  guaranteed,  putting  the 
project  implementation  schedule  at  risk.  Finally,  a  third  party 
contractor would not likely be able to operate Uzbekistan trains since 
this is the exclusive mandate of UTY.

Trade.  Intraregional  trade  is  growing  but  remains  seriously  constrained  because  of 
limited  transport  infrastructure  and  facilities.  Trade  is  increasing  between  Afghanistan  and 
Pakistan, Iran, and Central Asia. Annual growth rates exceed 10%. Total trade is now valued at 
$3.5  billion,  of  which  $500  million  are  exports  and  $3  billion  imports.  Volume  imports  exceed  
2 million tons. Afghanistan is the crucial link for Central Asia to access South Asian markets. It 
is also a conduit to access warm-water ports in Pakistan and on the Caspian Sea for trade with

A. 

Status of Transport Infrastructure and Services 

Afghanistan’s  transport  system  comprises  road,  rail,  air,  and  inland  waterways.  
1. 
The official road network spans 38,500 kilometers (km): 300 km of regional roads, 4,700 km of 
national roads, 9,700 km of provincial roads, 17,000 km of rural roads, and 3,800 km of urban 
roads.  The  total  length  of  railways  is  25  km,  which  are  cross-border  extensions  from 
Turkmenistan  and  Uzbekistan  to  transshipment  yards  in  Torghandi  and  Hairatan,  respectively 
(about 10 km and 15 km from the respective borders). Inland waterways are limited to the Amu 
Darya and its tributaries,1 although only the formal inland port at Shirkhan Bandar is operational 
at present. There are more than 60 airports and airfields spread across the country. There are 
two  international  and  22  domestic  airports  that  meet  International  Civil  Aviation  Organization 
(ICAO)  Class  4  categorization  standards.2 By  2010,  the  Kabul  International  Airport  and  Herat 
Airport  are  expected  to  achieve  full  international  ICAO  compliance  while  Mazar-e-Sharif, 
Jalalabad, and Kandahar airports will be upgraded.  
 
2. 
At the end of 2001, more than 90% of the transport system was unconnected and was in 
poor condition. Since then, the donors have helped improve key infrastructure, especially roads. 
About  86%  of  the  regional  road  network  is  scheduled  to  be  operational  by  end  2008  with  the 
remainder  to  be  completed  by  2010.  Work  is  underway  or  funding  has  been  obtained  for  the 
remaining  regional  roads,  with  the  exception  of  a  50  km  section  east  of  Herat.  The  improved 
roads  include  almost  2,100  km  (63%)  of  regional  roads,  650  km  (14%)  of  national  roads,  and 
6,000  km  of  provincial  and  rural  roads.  Roads  serve  90%  of  the  national  and  regional  travel 
demand. 
 
3. 
Rail services at Hairatan move about 250 wagons a day, while in Torghandi it is about 
50 wagons a day. The major imports are petroleum products and humanitarian food aid and at 
Torghandi, scrap metal is transshipped by truck to Pakistan. There is little reverse traffic except 
for  some  seasonal  fruit.  The  Kabul  International  Airport  handled  approximately  0.5  million 
international  and  domestic  passengers  in  2005,  and  civil  aviation  generated  about  $40  million 
from commercial over flights and airport taxes.   
 
4. 
In 2007, registered vehicles included over 300,000 cars, 40,000 buses, 100,000 trucks, 
100,000  motorcycles,  and  5,000  rickshaws.  Vehicle  numbers  increased  rapidly,  with  annual 
growth over the past 3 years of 23% for cars, 15% for trucks, 48% for motorcycles, but only 2% 
for buses and rickshaws. Virtually all vehicles are second-hand imports from Japan and Europe. 
 
5. 
Domestic  air  passenger  and  freight  services  are  provided  by  the  state  carrier  and 
several  private  carriers.  At  least  daily  flights  are  available  between  Kabul  and  most  cities.  
International  services  between  Kabul  and  several  Asian  destinations  are  provided  by  both 
national  and  international  carriers.  Airport  facilities  are  limited  and  in  a  poor  state  of  repair. 
Besides  Kabul,  Mazar-e-Sharif  is  the  only  main  airport  due  for  major  reconstruction  and 
expansion.  A  new  3,000  meter  runway  is  being  constructed.  About  600  meters  of  the  existing 
runway are being repaired, including new taxiways. This will increase capacity for the intermodal 
flow of commercial goods.

D. 

Government Plan for Railway Development 

14. 
Railway  development  is  a  solution  to  improve  undeveloped  regional  connectivity  as 
shown  in  the  problem  tree  analysis  (Figure  A2).  There  are  proposals  to  construct  three  new 
railway links into Afghanistan; one from the Pakistan border at Chaman to Kandahar; one from 
Sangan, in Iran territory, to Herat and the third from Hairatan (in Afghanistan, opposite from the 
Uzbekistan town of Termez) to Mazar-e-Sharif. The only one of these routes where railway track 
exists  within  Afghanistan  territory  is  in  the  Afghan  town  of  Hairatan.  Another  rail  line  enters 
Afghanistan  at  Torghandi,  just  across  the  Turkmenistan  border.  The  line  terminates  at 
Torghandi  with  commodities  (mostly  fuel)  transshipped  to  Afghan  trucks  for  further  movement 
within Afghanistan. The existing rail line from Termez, in Uzbekistan, currently terminates at the 
Afghanistan border town of Hairatan. Freight destined for Afghanistan, or beyond, is off-loaded 
at Hairatan and reloaded to Afghan trucks for movement through Afghanistan. 
 
15. 
The  Government  plans  to  develop  a  railway  network  in  north  Afghanistan  with  three 
main  sections:  (i)  Hairatan  to  Mazar-e-Sharif,  (ii)  Mazar-e-Sharif  to  Herat,  and  (iii)  Mazar-e-
Sharif  to  Tajikistan.  The  Government  top  priority  is  to  construct  a  new  railway  line  linking 
Hairatan with Mazar-e-Sharif. The primary transit traffic would be export cotton while most traffic 
destined  for  Afghanistan  moving  through  this  border  post  is  fuel.  At  the  present  time,  most  of 
Uzbekistan export cotton is moved by rail through Turkmenistan and Iran to the port of Bandar 
Abbas. An extension of the rail line into Afghanistan would make the new route to Charbakhar 
more attractive.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

A. 

Project Alternative and Rationale  

1. 
The freight movement between Hairatan and Mazar-e-Sharif increased from about 8,000 
ton in 2004 to about 12,000 ton in 2008 and is expected to increase slightly higher than the last 
7 years. Gross domestic product grew on average by about 11% per year. To accommodate the 
growing  demand  for  freight  transport,  two  options  could  be  considered:  (i)  expansion  of  the 
existing road, or (ii) building of a new railway line between Hairatan and Mazar-e-Sharif.  
 
2. 
Transport  costs  of  bulk  commodities  are  typically  cheaper  by  rail  than  road;  therefore, 
building a new railway line would result in significant savings of transport costs. The new railway 
line  will  also  divert  the  road  transport  to  rail  that  reduces  the  transport  costs  by  road,  traffic 
accidents, pollution, and green house gasses. The diversion of road to rail freight will reduce the 
road maintenance costs. It demonstrates that the proposed railway is the least cost option for 
meeting the growing freight demand. 
 
The  potential  demand  for  freight  by  rail  is  estimated  at  about  5,000  ton/day  at  the  first 
3. 
year of operation and in 2026 will reach approximately 30,000 ton/day, which is considered as 
the maximum capacity of the railway line.  
 
The existing rail line from Termez in Uzbekistan currently terminates at the Afghanistan 
4. 
border town of Hairatan. Freight destined for Afghanistan, or beyond, is off-loaded at Hairatan 
and  reloaded  to  Afghan  trucks  for  movement  in  or  through  Afghanistan.  The  Project  will 
construct a new railway line linking Hairatan with Mazar-e-Sharif (approximately 75 kilometers) 
and  rehabilitate  the  marshalling  yard  in  Hairatan.  The  new  railway  line  will  eventually  be 
extended to the southwest of the country to the Iranian border and to the port of Charbakhar.  
 
5. 
The Project railway line is part of the larger railway network in Afghanistan. The Project 
benefits will be higher once the railway network is completed. In the long run, the primary transit 
traffic  through  Afghanistan  will  potentially  be  cotton  from  Uzbekistan.  At  present,  most  of 
Uzbekistan's cotton export is moved by rail through Turkmenistan and Iran to the port of Bandar 
Abbas. An extension of the rail line into Afghanistan would make the new route to Charbakhar 
Port  in  Iran  more  attractive.  These  cotton  exports  could  be  routed  through  Afghanistan  to  the 
port of Charbakhar, if the route is to be constructed and improved. However, this will unlikely to 
happen within the short period and therefore will not be quantified in the economic analysis. 
 
B. 

Demand Forecast 

6. 
The  freight  traffic  on  the  existing  Hairatan–Naibabad–Mazar-e-Sharif  road  was  first 
projected. Then, the diversion potential of the freight traffic to the railway mode was considered.  
The  growth  rates  of  freight  travel  demand  have  been  obtained  by  multiplying  the  elasticity  of 
demand of freight traffic at the national level with respect to the dominant economic parameter 
with the expected growth rate of dominant economic parameter.   
 
7. 
The freight rail traffic is expected from regional freight currently transported by trucks and 
combined rail and truck. The freight can be divided into general and bulk cargo (mostly oil and 
gas  from  Uzbekistan).  It  is  assumed  that  oil  and  gas  transported  by  rail  will  continue  to  be 
transported by rail to be unloaded in Mazar-e-Sharif. General cargo is transported by either rail 
or  rail-road  transport.  General  cargo  currently  transported  by  rail  will  likely  to  use  the  new 
railway and some of those transported by road will shift to rail-road transport. Some will continue 
using road transport especially those originating from or going to cities beyond Naibabad.

C. 

Economic Analysis Approach 

8. 
An  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  comparing  with-  and  without-project  scenarios. 
The  base  case  reflects  expected  conditions  in  the  absence  of  the  Project,  with  maintenance 
sufficient  only  to  hold  the  railway  in  its  present  condition.  The  project  case  involves  initial 
investment followed by routine and periodic maintenance, but with expenditure and frequency of 
periodic  maintenance  economically  optimum.  All  costs  and benefits  are  expressed  in  constant 
mid-2009 prices. The economic analysis covers the construction period of 2 years plus 25 years 
of operation and maintenance. 
 
9. 
Economic analysis was conducted using border price numeraire. A standard conversion 
factor  for  non-tradable  goods  was  applied  to  calculate  the  economic  price  of  non-tradable 
goods. The shadow wage rates for skilled and unskilled labor were estimated by comparing the 
average  labor  wage  in  the  region  and  the  project  labor  wage,  taking  into  consideration  the 
existing  unemployment  rate.  The  shadow  wage  rates  for  skilled  and  unskilled  labor  were 
adjusted by the standard conversion factor.  
 
The  economic  costs  were  estimated  based  on  financial  costs,  including  physical 
10. 
contingencies. Price escalation, contingencies, and taxes were excluded. Financial costs were 
converted into economic costs using specific conversion factors of 0.98 for civil works and 0.90 
for railway maintenance. A specific conversion factor of 0.85 was used to convert the financial 
price of transport cost and time value savings. Economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) were 
calculated for various scenarios to evaluate the economic viability of the Project.

POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The  Government  gives  high  priority  to  the  Project.  The  Project  is  consistent  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)'s 
Country Partnership Strategy (2009–2013), which aims to enhance pro-poor economic growth through transport infrastructure 
development. The railway will serve as a key transport link for Afghanistan because it has significant mineral, industrial, and 
agricultural  potential,  which  requires  a  reliable  and  cost-effective  transport  system.  From  the  neighboring  countries  like 
Uzbekistan,  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  Pakistan,  all  imports  and  transit  goods  are  brought  to  the  borders  by  rail,  and  then 
transshipped onto the trucks for movement within Afghanistan or across the borders. The extraction of natural resources from 
major mines in Afghanistan requires a sustainable and safe mode of transport. Although the road network, which carries the 
majority of the country's freight and passenger traffic, is being improved, the transport system remains inadequate, inefficient, 
and  unsafe.  Only  half  of  the  roads  that  connect  24  provinces  of  the  country  are  serviceable  throughout  the  year,  greatly 
restricting job creation and economic growth. A railway network will complement roads. It will (i) offer an affordable means of 
mass  transport  for  sustained  growth  and  poverty  reduction,  (ii)  form  part  of  an  integrated  multimodal  transport  system  to 
enable  seamless  connectivity  from  origin  to  destination  for  goods  and  passengers,  and  (iii)  link  this  landlocked  country  to 
nearby seaports and trade centers.  
 
The  Project  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  by  (i)  constructing  a  railway  line  in  the  northern  region  of  Afghanistan,  (ii) 
serving  the  country  by  increased  economic  development,  employment  opportunities,  and  (iii)  contributing  to  the  social  and 
economic development in the region by facilitating the increased mobility and accessibility of goods across Afghanistan. The 
Project will increase access to urban markets for both agricultural and mineral products, and improve rural people access to 
education and health facilities.  
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
 
The  development  of  the  Project  area  is  suffering  with  insufficient  resources  of  supply  and  high  prices  of  agricultural  inputs, 
consumable goods, and construction materials. Local communities are not connected with regular transport system. Initiative 
for local investment and scope of employment is handicapped. All such situations due to insufficient and unsecured transport 
system. The community people deprived from uniform delivery of health services and technical and higher education.  
 
There is no official data on the rate of poverty for Afghanistan or the provinces. ADB estimated about 53% of Afghan people 
living in poverty. Most of them have a very low income. On average it is estimated about $2 per household per day. Including 
small  farmers,  landless  laborers,  ex-combatants,  war  widows,  war  orphans,  debtors,  sharecroppers,  returning  refugees, 
internally displaced persons about six million Afghans are vulnerable.  
 
The main causes of poverty in the project areas are insufficient scope of irrigation, lack of infrastructure, and very limited and 
unsustainable  sources  of  livelihood.  Drought  is  one  the  major  constraints  for  agriculture  and  livelihoods  development  in 
Afghanistan. 
 
The construction and operation of the project railway line will generate significant employment in local communities, which will 
be  targeted  at  local  communities  with  high  priorities  for  the  poor  and  vulnerable  people  of  surrounding  villages  or

which will create jobs for the poor and vulnerable peoples.  

The Project will enable local people and community to get easy access to market network and social services by creating a 
safe and cheaper transport network. Prices of essential commodities and construction materials will be cut. The initiative for 
rural and industrial development through exploiting local resources will increase. Local production and employment as well as
